translations.source_text: Mutations can have a variety of different effects depending on the type of mutation, the significance of the piece of genetic material affected and whether the cells affected are germ-line cells.
translations.pred_target_text: He maha nga awenga rereke ka pa mai ki te momo rerekee, te hiranga o te waahanga o nga mea ira e pa ana, me te mea ko nga pūtau e pangia ana he pūtau raina irariki.
translations.true_target_text: He maha ngā momo iranoi, kei runga i tōna momo e kitea ai ka pēhea e raru ai, ko te hihiri o te momo ira kua pāngia, ā, mēnā rānei he momo meroiti ngā ira e pāngia ana.

translations.source_text: Only mutations in germ-line cells can be passed on to children, while mutations elsewhere can cause cell-death or cancer.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga huringa i roto i nga rauropi iroriki anake ka taea te tuku ki nga tamariki, ko te whakarereketanga i etahi atu waahi ka mate-a-rorohiko te mate pukupuku ranei.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā rerekētanga anake ki ngā raina-ira ka tukuna ki te hunga tamariki, ko ētahi atu rā ka hua mai te mate-ira, te mate pukupuku rānei.

translations.source_text: Nature-based tourism attracts people interested in visiting natural areas for the purpose of enjoying the scenery, including plant and animal wildlife.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga tuuruhi-a-taiao e kukume ana i nga tangata e hiahia ana ki te haere ki nga waahi taiao mo te ngahau i nga tirohanga, tae atu ki nga tipu me nga kararehe kararehe.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te whakamanea te tāpoitanga ki te taiao i ngā tāngata e manawa reka ana te toro atu ki ngā wāhi māori mō te ngahau i te tirohanga te take, tae atu ki ngā tipu, ki ngā kararehe.

translations.source_text: Examples of on-site activities include hunting, fishing, photography, bird watching, and visiting parks and studying information about the ecosystem.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga tauira o nga mahi i runga i te waahi ko te hopu, te hī ika, te whakaahua, te tirotiro manu, me te haere ki nga papaa me te ako korero mo te rauwiringa kaiao.
translations.true_target_text: Hei whakatauira ake i ngā mahi ki konei, ko te aruaru, ko te hī ika, ko ngā mahi tango whakaahua, ko te mātai manu, ko te tirotiro whenua me te ako i ngā mōhiotanga e pā ana ki te taiao.

translations.source_text: An example is visiting, photographing, and learning about organgatuangs in Borneo.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko tetahi tauira ko te toro, ko te tango whakaahua, ko te ako mo nga organgatuang i Borneo.
translations.true_target_text: Ko tētahi tauira ko te toro, te mau whakaahua me te ako e pā ana ki ngā orangitangi ki Borneo.

translations.source_text: Every morning, people leave small country towns in cars to go their workplace and are passed by others whose work destination is the place they have just left.
translations.pred_target_text: Ia ata, ka wehe nga tangata i nga taone iti o te whenua ma runga motoka ki te haere ki o raatau waahi mahi, ka paahitia e etahi atu ko te waahi mahi ka wehe atu.
translations.true_target_text: Ia ata, ka wehewehe ngā tāngata i ngā tāone iti ki taiwhenua ki ngā waka ki te haere ki tō rātou wāhi mahi, ā, ka whakawhititia e ētahi atu ko tō rātou wāhi mahi ko te wāhi kātahi anō rātou ka wehe.

translations.source_text: In this dynamic transport shuttle everyone is somehow connected with, and supporting, a transport system based on private cars.
translations.pred_target_text: I roto i tenei waka waka hihiri e hono ana te katoa me te tautoko i tetahi punaha kawe i runga i nga motuka takitahi.
translations.true_target_text: I roto i tēnei pahi kawekawe uekaha nei kua honotahi, kua tautoko hoki te katoa i tētahi pūnaha kawenga e hāngai ana ki ngā waka tūmatawhāiti.

translations.source_text: Science now indicates that this massive carbon economy has dislodged the biosphere from one of its stable states that has supported human evolution for the past two million years.
translations.pred_target_text: E ai ki te Putaiao inaianei na tenei ohanga waro nui i mawehe atu i te koiora mai i tetahi o ona whenua pumau i tautoko i te whanaketanga o te tangata mo nga tau e rua miriona kua hipa.
translations.true_target_text: Ināianei, e tohu ana te pūtaiao ko te ohanga nui mō te waro kei te tūraki i te rangipūātea mai i tōna mauri tau, i manaakitia ai te ira tangata mō te 2 miriona tau ki muri.

translations.source_text: Everyone participates in society and uses transportation systems. Almost everyone complains about transportation systems.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka whai waahi nga tangata katoa ki te hapori me te whakamahi i nga punaha waka. Tata ki te katoa e amuamu ana mo nga punaha waka.
translations.true_target_text: Ka whai wāhi atu te kato ki ngā pūnaha mauranga. Ko te nuiga ka amuamu mō ngā pūnaha mauranga.

translations.source_text: In developed countries you seldom hear similar levels of complaints about water quality or bridges falling down.
translations.pred_target_text: I roto i nga whenua whakawhanake he iti noa te rongo i nga reanga rite o nga amuamu mo te kounga o te wai me nga piriti kua hinga.
translations.true_target_text: I ngā whenua kua whanake, me uaua ka rongo koe i ngā momo amuamu mō te pai o te wai, mō te turakitanga rānei o ngā piriti.

translations.source_text: Why do transportation systems engender such complaints, why do they fail on a daily basis? Are transportation engineers just incompetent? Or is something more fundamental going on?
translations.pred_target_text: He aha te take i puta ai nga amuamu penei i nga punaha kawe waka, he aha te take ka hinga i ia ra? He koretake noa nga miihini kawe waka? He mea nui ake ranei kei te haere tonu?
translations.true_target_text: He aha ka puta mai ngā amuamu pērā i ngā pūnaha ikiiki, ā, he aha ka hinga i ia rā? He koretake noa ngā kaipūkaha ikiiki? He take pūtake ake kei te haere rānei?

translations.source_text: Traffic Flow is the study of the movement of individual drivers and vehicles between two points and the interactions they make with one another.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te Rerenga Whakawhitiwhiti he rangahau mo te neke o nga taraiwa takitahi me nga waka i waenga i nga waahi e rua me nga taunekeneke ka mahia e ratou ki a raatau.
translations.true_target_text: Ko Traffic Flow te mātai i te rerenga o ngā kaitaraiwa takitahi me ngā waka i waenganui i ngā pūwāhi e rua me ngā pāhekoheko a tētahi ki tētahi.

translations.source_text: Unfortunately, studying traffic flow is difficult because driver behavior cannot be predicted with one-hundred percent certainty.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te mea pouri, he uaua te ako i te rerenga waka na te mea kaore e taea te matapae i te whanonga taraiwa me te kotahi rau paiheneti.
translations.true_target_text: E pōuri ana, he uaua te rangahau i te rere o ngā waka nā te mea e kore e taea te matapae i te whanonga taraiwa ki te mōhiotanga kotahi-rau ōrau.

translations.source_text: Fortunately, drivers tend to behave within a reasonably consistent range; thus, traffic streams tend to have some reasonable consistency and can be roughly represented mathematically.
translations.pred_target_text: Waimarie, ko nga kaitaraiwa e mahi ana i roto i te awhe tino rite; no reira, he rite tonu te ahua o nga rerenga waka, a ka taea te whakaatu i te pangarau.
translations.true_target_text: Maringanui, kei roto i te whānui āhua ū ngā whanonga noa o ngā kaitaraiwa; nō reira, ka āhua ōrite ngā ia waka, ā, ka taea te whakaata āwhiwhi ā-pāngarau.

translations.source_text: To better represent traffic flow, relationships have been established between the three main characteristics: (1) flow, (2) density, and (3) velocity.
translations.pred_target_text: Kia pai ake te whakaatu i te rere o te waka, kua whakaritea nga hononga i waenga i nga ahuatanga matua e toru: (1) rere, (2) kiato, me (3) tere.
translations.true_target_text: Kia pai ake te whakaatu i te rerenga waka, kua whakatūria ngā hononga i waenganui i ngā āhuatanga matua e toru: (1) te rere, (2) te apiapi, ā, (3) te tere.

translations.source_text: These relationships help in planning, design, and operations of roadway facilities.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka awhina enei hononga ki te whakamahere, te hoahoa me te whakahaere i nga waahi huarahi.
translations.true_target_text: He mea āwhina ēnei hononga ki te whakamahere, te hoahoa, me te mahi i ngā hanganga taha huarahi.

translations.source_text: Insects were the first animals to take to the air. Their ability to fly helped them evade enemies more easily and find food and mates more efficiently.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga pepeke nga kararehe tuatahi ka mau ki te rangi. Ko to ratou kaha ki te rere i awhina i a ratou ki te karo i nga hoariri me te rapu kai me nga hoa pai ake.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngārara ngā kararehe tuatahi i whai hā. Ko ō rātou pukenga ki te rere i māmā ake ai te ārai atu i ngā hoariri, ki te kai kai, ki te kimi hoa hoki.

translations.source_text: Most insects have the advantage of being able to fold their wings back along the body.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te painga o te nuinga o nga pepeke ka taea te kopaki i o ratou parirau ki muri i te tinana.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te nuinga o ngā pepeke te huanga o te āheinga ki te kōnumi i ō rātou parirau ki te tinana.

translations.source_text: This gives them a wider range of small places to hide from predators.
translations.pred_target_text: Ma tenei ka nui ake nga waahi iti hei hunanga mai i nga kaipahua.
translations.true_target_text: Mā korā ka whānui ake ngā wāhi iti hei huna i ngā konihi.

translations.source_text: Today, the only insects that cannot fold back their wings are dragon flies and mayflies.
translations.pred_target_text: I enei ra, ko nga ngarara anake e kore e taea te kopiri i o ratou parirau ko nga namu tarakona me nga namu.
translations.true_target_text: I tēnei rā, ko ngā pepeke e kore e taea te kōnumi i ō rātou parirau ko ngā uruururoroa, ko ngā piriwai anake.

translations.source_text: Thousands of years ago, a man called Aristarchus said that the Solar System moved around the Sun.
translations.pred_target_text: E hia mano tau ki muri, ka kii tetahi tangata ko Aristarchus te ingoa e huri haere ana te punaha solar i te ra.
translations.true_target_text: I ngā mano tau i mua, ko te tangata e kīa nei ko Aristarchus i kī ake ko te whānau a Tamanui te rā i huri rauna i te rā.

translations.source_text: Some people thought he was right but many people believed the opposite; that the Solar System moved around the Earth, including the Sun (and even the other stars).
translations.pred_target_text: Ko etahi i whakaaro he tika ia engari he maha nga tangata i whakapono ki te ritenga; i huri haere te Pūnaha Solar i te whenua, tae atu ki te Ra (me era atu whetu).
translations.true_target_text: I whakapono ētahi tāngata e tika ana ia engari ka rerekē te whakapono a ētahi; arā kia huri haere te Whānau a Tamanuiterā i te Ao, tae atu ki te Rā (tae rā anō ki ērā atu whetū).

translations.source_text: This seems sensible, because the Earth doesn't feel as if it's moving, does it?
translations.pred_target_text: He ahua mohio tenei, na te mea karekau te whenua i te ahua e neke ana, e tika?
translations.true_target_text: He whaitake te āhua, nā te mea kāore i te rangona te neke haeretanga o te ao, nē?

translations.source_text: The Amazon River is the second longest and the biggest river on Earth. It carries more than 8 times as much water as the second biggest river.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te awa o Amazon te awa tuarua o te awa roa rawa atu, te awa nui rawa atu hoki o te whenua. Neke atu i te 8 te nui ake o te wai e kawe ana i te awa tuarua.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te awa Amazon te awa nunui, roroa tuarua o te ao. Neke atu i te 8 reanga wai e pūritia ana e ia.

translations.source_text: The Amazon is also the widest river on Earth, at times six miles wide.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko Amazon te awa whanui rawa atu o te whenua, i etahi wa e ono maero te whanui.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te Amazon te awa whānui o Papatūānuku nei, e ono maero te whānuitanga.

translations.source_text: A full 20 percent of the water that pours out of the planet's rivers into the oceans comes from the Amazon.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te 20 paihēneti o te wai e maringi mai ana i nga awa o te ao ki nga moana ka ahu mai i te Amazon.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te ahu mai te nui o te 20 ōrau o te wai e rere ana i ngā awa o te ao ki ngā moana i te Amazon.

translations.source_text: The main Amazon River is 6,387 km (3,980 miles). It collects water from thousands of smaller rivers.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te awa matua o Amazon he 6,387 km (3,980 maero). Ka kohia he wai mai i nga mano tini awa iti.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te roa o te Amazon River matua ko te 6,387 km (3,980 maero). Kei te kohi ia i te wai mai i ngā tini mano awa iti iho.

translations.source_text: Although pyramid-building in stone continued until the end of the Old Kingdom, the pyramids of Giza were never surpassed in their size and the technical excellence of their construction.
translations.pred_target_text: Ahakoa i haere tonu te hanga koeko i roto i te kohatu tae noa ki te mutunga o te rangatiratanga Tawhito, kaore rawa nga koeko o Giza i eke ki te rahi me te hiranga hangarau o ta ratou hanga.
translations.true_target_text: Ahakoa i haere tonu te hanga-koeko ki te kohatu tae atu ki te mutunga o te Old Kingdom, kore rawa i pahika ngā koeko o Giza i te rahi me te kounga hangarau o te hanganga.

translations.source_text: New Kingdom ancient Egyptians marvelled at their predecessors monuments, which were then well over a thousand year old.
translations.pred_target_text: Ua maere roa te feia no Aiphiti tahito i te Basileia apî i to ratou mau ofai tahito, e ua hau atu i te hoê tausani matahiti.
translations.true_target_text: I mīharo ngā tāngata Īhipa tawhito New Kingtom ki ngā tohu whakamaumahara o ō rātou tūpuna, i taua wā ka nui ake i te kotahi mano tau te tawhito.

translations.source_text: Vatican City's population is around 800. It is the smallest independent country in the world and the country with the lowest population.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te taupori o Vatican City kei te tata ki te 800. Koia te whenua motuhake iti rawa o te ao me te whenua iti rawa te taupori.
translations.true_target_text: Tata ki te 800 te taupori o Vatican City. Koirā te whenua motuhake iti rawa o te ao, waihoki ko te whenua he iti rawa te taupori.

translations.source_text: Vatican City uses Italian in its legislation and official communications.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka whakamahi a Vatican City i te reo Itari i roto i ana ture me nga korero whai mana.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te reo ka whakamahia e te Whatikana ki roto i ōna ture me ōna pārongorongo ko te reo Itāria.

translations.source_text: Italian is also the everyday language used by most of those who work in the state while Latin is often used in religious ceremonies.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te reo Itariana te reo o ia ra e whakamahia ana e te nuinga o te hunga e mahi ana i roto i te kawanatanga i te nuinga o te wa e whakamahia ana te reo Latina ki nga huihuinga karakia.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te reo Itāria hoki te reo o ia rā e whakamahia ana e te nuinga o rātou e mahi ana ki te takiwā, ā, kei te tino whakamahia te reo Rātini ki ngā kawa ā-hāhi.

translations.source_text: All citizens of Vatican City are Roman Catholic.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga tangata katoa o Vatican City he Katorika Roma.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā kainoho katoa o Vatican City he Rōmana Katorika.

translations.source_text: People have known about basic chemical elements such as gold, silver, and copper from antiquity, as these can all be discovered in nature in native form and are relatively simple to mine with primitive tools.
translations.pred_target_text: Kua mohio nga tangata mo nga mea matū taketake penei i te koura, te hiriwa, me te parahi mai i nga wa onamata, i te mea ka kitea enei katoa i roto i te taiao i roto i te ahua taketake, he ngawari ki te maina me nga taputapu tawhito.
translations.true_target_text: Kua mōhio te tangata ki ngā pūmotu matū pūtake pērā i te koura, te hiriwa, te kapa mai rā anō, nā te mea ka taea te kite i te katoa o ēnei ki te taiao ki te āhuahanga tūturu, ā, he āhua māmā te maina ki ngā taputapu nō nehe.

translations.source_text: Aristotle, a philosopher, theorised that everything is made up of a mixture of one or more of four elements. They were earth, water, air, and fire.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko Aristotle, he philosopho, i kii ko nga mea katoa he ranunga o te kotahi neke atu ranei o nga mea e wha. He whenua, he wai, he hau, he ahi.
translations.true_target_text: Aristotle, te tangata whakaaro hohonu, i whakapae kua hanga ngā mea katoa i roto i ngā ranunga o tētahi o ngā pūmotu e whā. Ko te one, ko te wai, ko te hau me te ahi.

translations.source_text: This was more like the four states of matter (in the same order): solid, liquid, gas, and plasma, though he also theorised that they change into new substances to form what we see.
translations.pred_target_text: He rite tonu tenei ki nga ahuatanga e wha o te matū (i roto i te raupapa kotahi): totoka, wai, hau, me te plasma, ahakoa i kii ano ia ka huri hei matū hou hei hanga i nga mea e kitea ana e tatou.
translations.true_target_text: Ka pērā anō tēnei i ngā āhuatanga e whā o te matū (ki te raupapa ōrite): arā te totoka, te wē, te hau, te wētoto, ahakoa kua puta te ariā i a ia ka panoni ēnei ki ngā matū hou hei hanga i ngā mea e kitea ana e tātou.

translations.source_text: Alloys are basically a mixture of two or more metals. Don't forget that there are many elements on the periodic table.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga Alloys he ranunga o nga konganuku e rua neke atu ranei. Kaua e wareware he maha nga huānga kei runga i te ripanga wātaka.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā koranu ko te ranunga noa o ngā mētara e rua, neke atu rānei. Kauaka e wareware he nui ngā pūmotu ki te taka pūmotu

translations.source_text: Elements like calcium and potassium are considered metals. Of course, there are also metals like silver and gold.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga mea penei i te konupūmā me te pāhare pāporo ka kiia he konganuku. Ko te tikanga, he whakarewa ano he hiriwa me te koura.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā matū pērā i te konumohe me te konupūma e whai whakaarotia ana he mētara. Āe mārika, he mētara atu anō pēnei i te hiriwa me te koura.

translations.source_text: You can also have alloys that include small amounts of non-metallic elements like carbon.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka taea hoki e koe nga koranu kei roto i te iti o nga mea whakarewa-kore penei i te waro.
translations.true_target_text: Ka taea ngā kōranu e mau kōranu-kore ana mō ētahi mātū, pērā ki te waro.

translations.source_text: Everything in the Universe is made of matter. All matter is made of tiny particles called atoms.
translations.pred_target_text: He mea hanga nga mea katoa o te Ao. Ko nga matū katoa he mea hanga mai i nga matūriki iti e kiia nei he ngota.
translations.true_target_text: Ngā mea katoa o te ao nei kua hangaia ki te matū. Ko ngā matū katoa kua hangaia ki ngā mea iti nei e kīa nei ko te ngota.

translations.source_text: Atoms are so incredibly tiny that trillions of them could fit into the period at the end of this sentence.
translations.pred_target_text: He iti rawa nga ngota ka taea e nga piriona o ratou te uru ki roto i te waa i te mutunga o tenei rerenga korero.
translations.true_target_text: He pērā rawa te tino riki rawa o ngā ngota ka taea e ngā tini tiriona ngota te noho ki roto i te irakati ki te mutunga o tēnei rerenga.

translations.source_text: Thus, the pencil was a good friend to many people when it came out.
translations.pred_target_text: No reira, he hoa pai te pene ki te tini o nga tangata i tona putanga mai.
translations.true_target_text: Nā tēnā, i whakahoahoa ai te penerakau ki te tini tangata i te wā i hangaia mai.

translations.source_text: Sadly, as newer methods of writing have emerged, the pencil has been relegated to lesser status and uses.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te mea pouri, i te putanga mai o nga tikanga tuhituhi hou, kua heke te pene ki te iti ake te mana me te whakamahi.
translations.true_target_text: Te pōuri hoki, kua iti ake te mana me te whakamahinga o te pene rākau i te mea kua ara ake ētahi tikanga tuhituhi hou.

translations.source_text: People now write messages on computer screens, never having to come close to a sharpener.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka tuhi nga tangata i nga panui ki runga i nga mata rorohiko, kaua rawa e tata ki te whakakoi.
translations.true_target_text: Ka tuhia ngā karere ki runga rorohiko ināianei, hei aha noa iho te tāonga whakakoi

translations.source_text: One can only wonder what the keyboard will become when something newer comes along.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka taea e tetahi te whakaaro ka pehea te papapātuhi ina tae mai he mea hou ake.
translations.true_target_text: Ka taea anake te whai whakaaro ake ka ahatia ki te papa pātuhi inā ka puta mai tētahi mea hou.

translations.source_text: The fission bomb works on the principle that it takes energy to put together a nucleus with many protons and neutrons.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka mahi te poma wehenga i runga i te maapono me kaha ki te whakakotahi i tetahi karihi me te maha o nga iraoho me nga neutrons.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te tikanga o te pahū fission he hari i te ngoi hei whakaemi i nukara he tini ngā iraoho me ngā iramoe.

translations.source_text: Sort of like rolling a heavy cart up a hill. Splitting the nucleus up again then releases some of that energy.
translations.pred_target_text: He rite ki te huri i te kaata taumaha ki runga puke. Ka wehea ano te karihi ka puta etahi o taua kaha.
translations.true_target_text: E takahurihuri ana pēnei i ngā kāta tumaha mā runga i te puke. E whakawehe nei anō i te poka pū, ka tukuna ai ētahi o taua ngoi.

translations.source_text: Some atoms have unstable nuclei which means that they tend to break apart with little or no nudging.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko etahi ngota he karihi taupatupatu, ko te tikanga ka pakaru noa ki te iti, ki te kore ranei e tuo.
translations.true_target_text: He karihi pāhekeheke kei ētahi ngota, nā korā ka whakawehi ai ahakoa kāore he tuke, he iti rānei te tuke.

translations.source_text: The surface of the Moon is made of rocks and dust. The outer layer of the Moon is called the crust.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te mata o te Marama he toka me te puehu. Ko te paparanga o waho o te Marama ka kiia ko te kirinuku.
translations.true_target_text: Kua hangaia te mata o te Marama ki ngā kōhatu me te puehu. E kīia ana ko te papa ā-waho o te Marama ko te kirimarama.

translations.source_text: The crust is about 70 km thick on the near side and 100 km thick on the far side.
translations.pred_target_text: Tata ki te 70 kiromita te matotoru o te kirinuku ki te taha tata me te 100 kiromita ki te taha tawhiti.
translations.true_target_text: He tata ki te 70 km te mātotoru o te kirinuku ki te taha tata, ā, e 100 km te mātotoru ki te taha tawhiti.

translations.source_text: It is thinner under the maria and thicker under the highlands.
translations.pred_target_text: He angiangi ake i raro i te maria, he matotoru i raro i nga maunga.
translations.true_target_text: Ko raro i te maria he tūpuhi, ki tuawhenua he whānui ake.

translations.source_text: There may be more maria on the near side because the crust is thinner. It was easier for lava to rise up to the surface.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka nui ake pea te maria i te taha tata na te mea he kikokore te kirinuku. He ngawari ake te piki ake o te rangitoto ki te mata.
translations.true_target_text: Ka nui ake pea te maria ki te taha tata i te mea he kōrahirahi ake te kirinuku. He māmā ake kia whanake ake te tahepuia ki te mata.

translations.source_text: Content theories are centered on finding what makes people tick or appeals to them.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga ariā ihirangi e aro ana ki te rapu he aha te mea e pai ai te tangata ki a raatau.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te ngako o ngā ariā kiko ko te rapu i ngā mea e tino whakaoho ana i te tangata, e pai ana ki a rātou rānei.

translations.source_text: These theories suggest that people have certain needs and/or desires which have been internalized as they mature to adulthood.
translations.pred_target_text: E ai ki enei ariā he hiahia, he hiahia hoki/ranei te tangata i roto i to ratou pakeketanga ki te pakeketanga.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te marohi ēnei ariā kei ētahi tāngata he hiahia, he pīrangi hoki/rānei kua whakatōngia ki roto i a rātou e pakeke haere ana ki te pakeketanga.

translations.source_text: These theories look at what it is about certain people that make them want the things that they do and what things in their environment will make them do or not do certain things.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka tirohia e enei ariā he aha nga mea e pa ana ki etahi tangata e hiahia ana ratou ki nga mahi e mahia ana e ratou me nga mea o to taiao e kaha ai ratou ki te mahi, ki te kore ranei e mahi i etahi mahi.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te aro atu ēnei ariā ki ngā āhuatanga o ētahi tāngata e tuku ana i a rātou ki te hiahia i ngā mea e hiahiatia ana e rātou, ā, he aha ngā mea ki tō rātou taiao ka whakarite i a rātou ki te mahi, ki te kore mahi rānei i ētahi mahi.

translations.source_text: Two popular content theories are Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory and Hertzberg's Two Factor Theory.
translations.pred_target_text: E rua nga ariā ihirangi rongonui ko Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs Theory me Hertzberg's Two Factor Theory.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā ariā kiko rorotu e rua ko te Hierarchy of Needs Theory a Maslow, me te Two Factor Theory a Hertzberg.

translations.source_text: Generally speaking, two behaviors can emerge as managers begin to lead their former peers. One end of the spectrum is trying to remain “one of the guys” (or gals).
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te tikanga, e rua nga whanonga ka puta i te wa e timata ana nga kaiwhakahaere ki te arahi i o raatau hoa o mua. Ko tetahi pito o te tuāwhiorangi kei te ngana ki te noho "tetahi o nga taane" (te kotiro ranei).
translations.true_target_text: I te nuinga o te wā, e rua ngā whanonga ka puta mai pea i te tīmatanga o ngā kaiwhakahaere te ārahi i ō rātou hoamahi o mua. Ki tētahi pito ko te ngana ki te noho tonu hei "tētahi o ngā autaia" (ngā kō rānei).

translations.source_text: This type of manager has difficulty making unpopular decisions, performing disciplinary action, performance evaluations, assigning responsibility, and holding people accountable.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko tenei momo kaiwhakahaere he uaua ki te whakatau i nga whakatau kaore e paingia ana, ki te whakahaere i nga mahi whiu, ki te arotake i nga mahi, ki te tuku kawenga, me te pupuri i nga tangata hei kawenga.
translations.true_target_text: He uaua ki tēnei momo kaiwhakahaere te whakatau i ngā whakatau kāore e rataina, te whakamahi i ngā mahi whakatika, te arotake mahi, te tuku haepapa, me te whakarite kia noho haepapa ngā tāngata.

translations.source_text: At the other end of the spectrum, one morphs into an unrecognizable individual that feels he or she must change everything the team has been doing and make it their own.
translations.pred_target_text: I tetahi atu pito o te tuāwhiorangi, ka huri tetahi ki tetahi tangata e kore e mohiotia e whakaaro ana me whakarereke e ia nga mea katoa i mahia e te roopu me te hanga i a raatau ake.
translations.true_target_text: Ki tērā atu pito o te whānuitanga, ka huri tētahi ki tētahi takitahi kāore e mōhiotia ana ki a ia me panoni ia i ngā mahi katoa kua mahia e te rōpū kia noho ko tōna ake.

translations.source_text: After all, the leader is ultimately responsible for the success and failure of the team.
translations.pred_target_text: I muri i nga mea katoa, ko te rangatira te kawenga mo te angitu me te kore o te kapa.
translations.true_target_text: Waihoki, kei te noho haepapa te kaiārahi mō te eke me te hinga o te kapa.

translations.source_text: This behavior oftentimes results in rifts between the leaders and the rest of the team.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko tenei whanonga he maha nga wa ka puta he raruraru i waenga i nga kaiarahi me era atu o te roopu.
translations.true_target_text: He nui ngā wā ka puta i tēnei whanonga ngā wehenga i waenganui i ngā kaiārahi me te toenga o te rōpū.

translations.source_text: Virtual teams are held to the same standards of excellence as conventional teams, but there are subtle differences.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga kapa mariko e mau ana ki nga paerewa o te hiranga ki nga roopu tikanga, engari he rereke nga rereketanga.
translations.true_target_text: E mau nei te taumata kōunga mō ngā roopū mariko ki ngā tīma taketake, heoi he rerekētanga iti nei.

translations.source_text: Virtual team members often function as the point of contact for their immediate physical group.
translations.pred_target_text: He maha nga mahi a nga mema o te roopu mariko hei waahi whakapiri mo o raatau roopu tinana.
translations.true_target_text: I ētahi wā ka noho ngā mema tīma mariko hei āhuatanga whakapākanga mō tō rātou rōpū ā-kiko tata.

translations.source_text: They often have more autonomy than conventional team members as their teams may meet according to varying time zones which may not be understood by their local management.
translations.pred_target_text: He maha ake o ratou mana motuhake atu i nga mema o te roopu tikanga na te mea ka hui pea a ratau kapa i runga i nga waahi rerekee kaore pea i te maarama e nga kaiwhakahaere o to rohe.
translations.true_target_text: I te nuinga o te wā he nui ake tō rātou tino rangatiratanga tēnā i ngā mema o ngā tīma noa, i te mea ko ā rātou tīma ka hui kei te āhua o ngā rohe wā rerekē ka kore pea e māramatia e tā rātou kaiwhakahaere ā-rohe.

translations.source_text: The presence of a true “invisible team” (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) is also a unique component of a virtual team.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te aroaro o te "tiima e kore e kitea" (Larson me LaFasto, 1989, p109) he waahanga motuhake ano o te roopu mariko.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te noho mai o tētahi "kapa kāore i te kitea" tūturu (Larson and LaFasto, 1989, p109) hoki tētahi wāhanga ahurei o tētahi kapa mariko.

translations.source_text: The “invisible team” is the management team to which each of the members report. The invisible team sets the standards for each member.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te "tiima e kore e kitea" ko te roopu whakahaere e ripoata ana ia mema. Ko te roopu e kore e kitea nga paerewa mo ia mema.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te "tīma kore kitea" te tīma whakahaere e noho ai hei rīpoatatanga mā ngā mema. Ka whakatū te tīma kore kitea ngā taumata mō ia mema.

translations.source_text: Why would an organization want to go through the time consuming process of establishing a learning organization? One goal for putting organizational learning concepts into practice is innovation.
translations.pred_target_text: He aha i hiahia ai tetahi whakahaere ki te haere i roto i te wa roa mo te whakatu i tetahi whakahaere ako? Ko tetahi o nga whainga ki te whakatinana i nga kaupapa ako whakahaere ko te mahi auaha.
translations.true_target_text: He aha i hiahia ai tētahi umanga te mahi i tētahi hātepe whakapau wā ki te whakarite i tētahi umanga whakaako? Ko tētahi whāinga mō te whakamahi i ngā kaupapa ako ki roto i tētahi parakatihi auaha.

translations.source_text: When all available resources are effectively used across the functional departments of an organization, creativity and ingenuity can transpire.
translations.pred_target_text: Ina whakamahia nga rauemi katoa puta noa i nga tari mahi o te whakahaere, ka puta te mahi auaha me te mohio.
translations.true_target_text: I te wā he pai te whakamahi i ngā rawa katoa e wātea ana whakawhiti atu i ngā tari mahi o tētahi whakahaere, ka ara ake pea te auaha me te atamai.

translations.source_text: As a result, the process of an organization working together to overcome an obstacle can lead to a new innovative process to serve the customer's need.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te mutunga mai, ko te mahi a te whakahaere e mahi tahi ana ki te hinga i tetahi arai ka arahi ki tetahi mahi hou hei whakatutuki i nga hiahia o te kaihoko.
translations.true_target_text: Me te aha, ko te hātepe o tētahi whakahaere e mahi tahi ana kia eke panuku i tētahi ārai e taea ai te arataki ki tētahi hātepe auaha hou hei whakarato i tā te kiritaki hiahia.

translations.source_text: Before an organization can be innovative, leadership must create a culture of innovation as well as shared knowledge and organizational learning.
translations.pred_target_text: I mua i te mahi auaha o te whakahaere, me hanga e te kaihautu he tikanga auaha me te tuku matauranga me te ako whakahaere.
translations.true_target_text: E maromahue ai tētahi hinonga, me whakatōkia e ōna rangatira tētahi momo wairua maromahue, te tuari mātauranga, me tēnei mea te ako hoki.

translations.source_text: Angel (2006), explains the Continuum approach as a method being used to help organizations reach a higher level of performance.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko Angel (2006), te whakamarama i te huarahi Continuum hei tikanga e whakamahia ana hei awhina i nga whakahaere ki te eke ki te taumata teitei ake o nga mahi.
translations.true_target_text: E whakamārama ana a Angel (2006) i te huarahi Kore-otinga hei tikanga ārahi i ngā rōpū whakahaere kia eke ai rātou ki ngā taumata e whāia ana.

translations.source_text: Neurobiological data provide physical evidence for a theoretical approach to the investigation of cognition. Therefore it narrows the research area and makes it much more exact.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga raraunga neurobiological e whakarato ana i nga taunakitanga tinana mo te huarahi ariā ki te tirotiro i te mohiotanga. Na reira ka whakawhāitihia te waahi rangahau, ka tino tika ake.
translations.true_target_text: Kei ngā raraunga koiora-ā-io ngā whakaaturanga ā-kiko mō tētahi aronga ā-ariā ki te mātai i te whakaaroaro. Nā reira māna te kaupapa rangahau e whakawhāiti, ā, ka pū ake hoki te aronga.

translations.source_text: The correlation between brain pathology and behaviour supports scientists in their research.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te hononga i waenga i te mate roro me te whanonga e tautoko ana i nga kaiputaiao ki a raatau rangahau.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te tautoko te hāngaitanga i waenganui i te pānga hinengaro me te whanonga i ngā kaipūtaiao ki ā rātou rangahau.

translations.source_text: It has been known for a long time that different types of brain damage, traumas, lesions, and tumours affect behaviour and cause changes in some mental functions.

translations.true_target_text: I tēnei wā, he tāone tino pōhara a Timbuktu, ahakoa he whakamaneatanga tūruhi i runga i tōna rongo, ā, he tauranga waka rererangi ki reira.

translations.source_text: In 1990, it was added to the list of world heritage sites in danger, due to the threat of desert sands.
translations.pred_target_text: I te tau 1990, i whakaurua ki te rarangi o nga waahi tuku iho o te ao kei te noho morearea, na te riri o te onepu koraha.
translations.true_target_text: I te tau 1990, i tāpiritia ia ki te rārangi o ngā wāhi world heritage e mōrearea ana, i runga i te whakatuma o ngā oneone koraha.

translations.source_text: It was one of the major stops during Henry Louis Gates' PBS special Wonders of the African World.
translations.pred_target_text: Koia tetahi o nga tuunga nui i te wa o Henry Louis Gates nga Whakamiharo motuhake o te PBS o te Ao Awherika.
translations.true_target_text: Koirā tētahi o ngā tūnga matua i te wā o te PBS special Wonders of the African World o Henry Louis Gates.

translations.source_text: The city is in stark contrast to the rest of the country's cities, because it has more of an Arabic flair than of an African.
translations.pred_target_text: He tino rerekee te taone nui ki era atu taone o te motu, na te mea he nui ake te ahua o te reo Arapi i to te tangata Afirika.
translations.true_target_text: He tīno rerekē te tāone i te toinga atu o ngā tāone o te whenua, i te mea he tāera Arabi tēnā i te Awherika.

translations.source_text: The Kruger National Park (KNP) lies in the north-east of South Africa and runs along the border of Mozambique in the east, Zimbabwe in the north, and the southern border is the Crocodile River.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te Kruger National Park (KNP) kei te raki-ma-rawhiti o Awherika ki te Tonga, ka rere i te rohe o Mozambique ki te rawhiti, ko Zimbabwe ki te raki, ko te rohe ki te tonga ko te awa o Crocodile.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te raki mā rāwhiti o Āwherika ki te Tonga te Kruger National Park (KNP), ā, kei te pae o Mozambique ki te rāwhiti, ki Zimbabwe ki te raki, ā, ko te pae tonga ko te Crocodile River.

translations.source_text: The park covers 19,500 km² and is divided in 14 different ecozones, each supporting different wildlife.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te 19,500 km² te rahi o te papa, ka wehea ki nga rohe kaiao rereke 14, e tautoko ana ia kararehe mohoao rereke.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te hōkai 19,500 km₂ te rahi o te pāka, ā, kei te whakawehea ki ngā wāhi rauropi 14 rerekē, kei te tautīnei ia wāhi i ngā karerehe rerekē.

translations.source_text: It is one of the main attractions of South Africa and it is considered the flagship of South African National Parks (SANParks).
translations.pred_target_text: Koia tetahi o nga tino waahi o Awherika ki te Tonga ka kiia ko te tino rangatira o nga Paaka Motu o Awherika ki te Tonga (SANParks).
translations.true_target_text: Koirā tētahi o ngā mea whakamanea matua o Awherika ki te Tonga, ā, e whai whakaarohia ana ia hei tohu matua o ngā South African National Parks (SANParks).

translations.source_text: As with all South African National Parks, there are daily conservation and entry fees for the park.
translations.pred_target_text: Pērā ki ngā Pāka ā-Motu o Awherika ki te Tonga, he utu tiaki mo ia ra me te utu whakaurunga mo te papa.
translations.true_target_text: Mō ngā Rohenga Wao Nui o Aherika ki te Tonga, he utu e hāngai ana i te urunga ki ngā rohenga.

translations.source_text: It may also be beneficial for one to buy a Wild Card, which provides entry to either selections of parks in South Africa or all of the South African National Parks.
translations.pred_target_text: He painga ano pea mo te tangata ki te hoko i tetahi Kaari Mohoao, e uru ana ki nga whiringa papa i Awherika ki te Tonga, ki te katoa ranei o nga Paaka Motu o Awherika ki te Tonga.
translations.true_target_text: He whaihua pea kia hokona tētahi Wild Card, māna e tuku te kuhunga atu ki ētahi kōwhiringa o ngā pāka ki Āwherika ki te Tonga, ki te katoa rānei o ngā South African National Parks.

translations.source_text: Hong Kong Island gives the territory of Hong Kong its name and is the place that many tourists regard as the main focus.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te Moutere o Hong Kong te ingoa o te rohe o Hong Kong, a ko te waahi e kiia ana e te tini o nga turuhi te kaupapa matua.
translations.true_target_text: Nā Hong Kong Island te ingoa o te rohe o Hong Kong, ā, koirā te wāhi ka whakaarohia e ngā tini tūruhi hei aronga matua.

translations.source_text: The parade of buildings that make the Hong Kong skyline has been likened to a glittering bar chart that is made apparent by the presence of the waters of Victoria Harbour.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te parade o nga whare e hangai ana i te rangi o Hong Kong kua whakaritea ki te tutohi pae kanapa e kitea ana e nga wai o te whanga o Wikitoria.
translations.true_target_text: Kua kōrerotia te tini o ngā whare nunui e hanga ai i te huapae o Hong Kong anō nei ko te pae mahere pīataata e mōhio whānuitia ana e ngā wai o Victoria Harbour.

translations.source_text: To get the best views of Hong Kong, leave the island and head for the Kowloon waterfront opposite.
translations.pred_target_text: Ki te kite i nga tirohanga pai o Hong Kong, wehe atu i te motu ka anga ki te taha moana o Kowloon i te ritenga atu.
translations.true_target_text: Ki te kite i ngā tirohanga rawe rawa atu o Hong Kong, me wehe i te motu ka haere ai ki te tāhuna Kowloon kei tērā atu taha.

translations.source_text: The great majority of Hong Kong Island's urban development is densely packed on reclaimed land along the northern shore.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te nuinga o nga whanaketanga taone o Hong Kong kei te kikii ki runga i nga whenua kua tangohia i te takutai raki.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te kiato te nuinga o te whanaketanga ā-tāone o Hong Kong Island ki te whenua taumanu ki te taha o te tai raki.

translations.source_text: This is the place the British colonisers took as their own and so if you are looking for evidence of the territory's colonial past, this is a good place to start.
translations.pred_target_text: Koinei te waahi i tangohia e nga tangata whenua o Ingarangi mo ratou ake, no reira mena kei te rapu koe mo nga tohu o te koroni o mua o te rohe, he waahi pai tenei ki te timata.
translations.true_target_text: Koinei te wāhi i tangohia e te hunga koroniara nō Peretānia mō rātou anō, nō reira ki te rapu koe i te taunakitanga o te hītori koroniara o te takiwā, koinei tētahi wāhi pai hei tīmata.

translations.source_text: The Sundarbans are the largest littoral mangrove belt in the world, stretching 80 km (50 mi) into the Bangladeshi and Indian hinterland from the coast.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga Sundarbans te whitiki mangrove nui rawa atu o te ao, e 80 kiromita (50 mi) te toro atu ki te tuawhenua o Bangladeshi me Inia mai i te takutai.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā Sundarbans ngā tātua ritora mangrove nui rawa i te ao, e toro ana i te 80 km (50 mairo) ki roto ki te Bangladeshi me te Iniana whenuaroto tae atu ki te takutai.

translations.source_text: The Sundarbans has been declared a UNESCO World Heritage Site. The part of the forest within Indian territory is called Sundarbans National Park.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga Sundarbans kua kiia ko te UNESCO World Heritage Site. Ko te waahi o te ngahere i roto i te rohe o Inia e kiia ana ko Sundarbans National Park.
translations.true_target_text: I ehakatauhia ko te Sundarbans he UNESCO World Heritage Site. Ko te ingoa o te wāhanga ngahere kei te rohe Inia, ko Sundarbans National Park.

translations.source_text: The forests aren't just mangrove swamps though — they include some of the last remaining stands of the mighty jungles which once covered the Gangetic plain.
translations.pred_target_text: Ehara i te mea he repo mangrove noa nga ngahere - kei roto ko etahi o nga tuunga whakamutunga o nga ngahere nunui i kapi i te mania Gangetic.
translations.true_target_text: Ehara noa ngā ngahengahe nei i te repo waikure - kei roto ētahi o ngā tūnga whakamutunga o te ngahengahe nunui i kapi ai i te raorao Gangetic.

translations.source_text: The Sundarbans cover an area of 3,850 km², of which about one-third is covered in water/marsh areas.
translations.pred_target_text: He 3,850 km² te rahi o nga Sundarbans, tata ki te kotahi hautoru kei roto i nga waahi wai.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te horahanga o te 3,850 km2 ngā Sundarbans, ā, ko te kotahi-hautoru e whakakapia ana ki ngā wāhi wai/kōreporepo.

translations.source_text: Since 1966 the Sundarbans have been a wildlife sanctuary, and it is estimated that there are now 400 Royal Bengal tigers and about 30,000 spotted deer in the area.
translations.pred_target_text: Mai i te tau 1966 kua noho nga Sundarbans hei whare mohoao, e kiia ana kua 400 nga taika Royal Bengal inaianei me te 30,000 nga tia purepure kei te takiwa.
translations.true_target_text: Mai i te 1966 kua noho iho te Sundarbans hei whakamaurutanga mohoao, ā, e ai ki te kōrero he 400 ngā tāika ariki Bengal me ngā tia korotiwhatiwha e 30,000 i roto i te wāhi.

translations.source_text: Buses depart the inter-district bus station (across the river) throughout the day, though most, especially those heading to the east and Jakar/Bumthang leave between 06:30 and 07:30.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka wehe nga pahi i te teihana pahi-a-rohe (i tera taha o te awa) puta noa i te ra, ahakoa ko te nuinga, ina koa ko te hunga e ahu atu ana ki te rawhiti ka wehe atu a Jakar/Bumthang i waenga i te 06:30 me te 07:30.
translations.true_target_text: Ka wehe ngā pahi i te teihana kei te pokapū (kei tērā atu taha o te awa) i te wā e awatea ana, ahakoa ko te nuinga, mātua rā, ko ērā e haere whaka te raki ana, tae atu anō hoki ki a Jakar/Bumthang ka wehe mai i te 6.30 ki te 7.30.

translations.source_text: As the inter-district buses are often full, it is advisable to purchase a ticket a few days in advance.
translations.pred_target_text: I te mea e kiki ana nga pahi i waenganui i nga takiwa, he mea pai kia hokona he tikiti i etahi ra i mua.
translations.true_target_text: I runga i te noho kī o ngā pahi waenga-rohe i te nuinga o ngā wā, he rautaki pai te hoko tīkiti ētahi rā i mua.

translations.source_text: Most districts are served by small Japanese Coaster Buses, which are comfortable and sturdy.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te nuinga o nga takiwa e mahihia ana e nga pahi iti Japanese Coaster, he pai, he pakari.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te nuinga o ngā rohe ko ngā Japanese Coaster Buses paku, he āhuru, he pakari anō hoki.

translations.source_text: Shared taxis are a quick and comfortable means to travel to nearby places, such as Paro (Nu 150) and Punakha (Nu 200).
translations.pred_target_text: He tere, he pai hoki te haere ki nga waahi tata, penei i Paro (Nu 150) me Punakha (Nu 200) nga taxis tiritahi.
translations.true_target_text: He tere ake, he hāneanea ake te tuari tēkehi ki te haereere ki ngā wahi e tata ana, pērā ki a Paro (Nu 150) me Punkha (Nu 200).

translations.source_text: The Oyapock River Bridge is a cable-stayed bridge. It spans the Oyapock River to link the cities of Oiapoque in Brazil and Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock in French Guiana.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te Piriti Awa o Oyapock he piriti noho taura. Ka toro atu ki te awa o Oyapock hei hono i nga taone o Oiapoque i Brazil me Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock i French Guiana.
translations.true_target_text: He piriti here-taura te Oyapock River Bridge. Ka whakawhiti atu i te Oyapock River hei tūhono i ngā tāone nui o Oiapoque ki Parīhi, me Saint-Georges de l'Oyapock ki French Guiana.

translations.source_text: The two towers rise to a height of 83 meters, it's 378 meters long and it has two lanes of 3.50 m wide.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka piki nga pourewa e rua ki te 83 mita te teitei, 378 mita te roa, e rua ona ara e 3.50 mita te whanui.
translations.true_target_text: Ka piki te teitei o ngā pourewa e rua ki te 83 mita, ā, e 378 mita te roa, e rua ngā ara o te 3.50 m te whānui.

translations.source_text: The vertical clearance under the bridge is 15 meters. Construction was completed in August 2011, it didn't open to traffic until March 2017.
translations.pred_target_text: He 15 mita te whakawātea poutū i raro i te piriti. I oti te hanga i te marama o Akuhata 2011, kare i tuwhera ki nga waka tae noa ki Maehe 2017.
translations.true_target_text: He 15 mita te poutū māhea o raro iho i te piriti. I oti te hanganga i te Ākuhata 2011, kāore i whakatuwhera mō ngā waka tae rawa ki te marama o Māehe i te tau 2017.

translations.source_text: The bridge is scheduled to be fully operational in September 2017, when the Brazilian customs checkpoints are expected to be finished.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te piriti kua whakaritea kia tino mahi i te marama o Mahuru 2017, i te wa e tika ana kia mutu nga waahi tirotiro a Brazilia.
translations.true_target_text: Kua whakaritea kia pai katoa ngā mahi a te piriti hei te Mahuru o te tau 2017, hei taua wā kua oti pea ngā wāhi tirotiro hei ārai o Parihi.

translations.source_text: The Guaraní were the most significant indigenous group inhabiting what is now Eastern Paraguay, living as semi-nomadic hunters who also practised subsistence agriculture.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga Guaraní te roopu tangata whenua tino nui e noho ana i te Paraguay ki te Rawhiti, e noho ana hei kaihopu noho manene e mahi ana i nga mahi ahuwhenua oranga.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te Guarani te iwi taketake hira rawa e noho ana ki te whenua e kīia ana ko Eastern Paraguay ināianei, i te noho hei kaiaruaru āhua-tipiwhenua, i te mahi hoki i te ahuwhenua mā rātou anō.

translations.source_text: The Chaco region was home to other groups of indigenous tribes such as the Guaycurú and Payaguá, who survived by hunting, gathering and fishing.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te rohe o Chaco te kainga mo etahi atu roopu o nga iwi taketake penei i a Guaycurú me Payaguá, i ora mai i te hopu, te kohikohi me te hī ika.
translations.true_target_text: I nōhia ai te rohe Chaco e ngā iwi taketake pērā ki ngā Guaycur'u me ngā Payagu'a, i ora ai rātou i te whai kararehe me te hī ika.

translations.source_text: In the 16th century Paraguay, formerly called "The Giant Province of the Indies", was born as a result of the encounter of Spanish conquerors with the native indigenous groups.
translations.pred_target_text: I te rautau 1600 i whanau mai a Paraguay, i kiia i mua ko "Te Porowini Nui o Inia", na te tukinga o nga raupatu Paniora me nga roopu tangata whenua.
translations.true_target_text: I te rautau 16, i whānau mai a Paraguay, ko tōna ingoa kārangaranga hoki ko "Te Rohe nui o ngā Indies," i ngā taukumekume i ngā waenganui i ngā kairaupatu o Pāniora me ngā iwi taketake.

translations.source_text: The Spaniards started the colonization period which lasted for three centuries.
translations.pred_target_text: I timata nga Paniora i te wa o te koroni e toru nga rau tau.
translations.true_target_text: I tīmata te iwi Pāniora ki ngā mahi raupatu, toru rautau te roa.

translations.source_text: Since the foundation of Asunción in 1537, Paraguay has managed to keep a lot of its indigenous character and identity.
translations.pred_target_text: Mai i te turanga o Asunción i te tau 1537, kua kaha a Paraguay ki te pupuri i te maha o ona ahuatanga taketake me tona tuakiri.
translations.true_target_text: Mai i te orokohanganga mai o Asunciōn i te 1537, kia kaha a Paraguay ki te mau tonu ki te nuinga o ngā tāngata whenua me tōna tuakiri.

translations.source_text: Argentina is well known for having one of the best polo teams and players in the world.
translations.pred_target_text: Kei te rongonui a Argentina mo tetahi o nga kapa polo me nga kaitakaro pai o te ao.
translations.true_target_text: E mōhio whānuitia nei a Argentina mō tētahi o ngā tīma me ngā kaitākaro papai rawa o te ao mō te polo.

translations.source_text: The largest tournament of the year takes place in December at the polo fields in Las Cañitas.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te whakataetae nui rawa atu o te tau ka tu hei te Hakihea ki nga papa polo i Las Cañitas.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te whakataetae nui rawa o te tau ka tū i te marama o Tīhema i ngā papa polo i Las Nanitas.

translations.source_text: Smaller tournaments and matches can also be seen here at other times of the year.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga whakataetae me nga whakataetae iti ka kitea i konei i etahi atu wa o te tau.
translations.true_target_text: Ka kitea hoki ngā taiwhanga iti me ngā whakataetae ki konei i ētahi atu wāhanga o te tau.

translations.source_text: For news on tournaments and where to buy tickets for polo matches, check Asociacion Argentina de Polo.
translations.pred_target_text: Mo nga korero mo nga whakataetae me nga waahi hoko tikiti mo nga whakataetae polo, tirohia te Asociacion Argentina de Polo.
translations.true_target_text: Mō ngā pūrongo e pā ana ki ngā tauwhāinga me ngā wāhi hoko tikiti mō ngā kēmu pōro, tirohia Asociacion Argentina de Polo.

translations.source_text: The official Falklands currency is the Falkland pound (FKP) whose value is set equivalent to that of one British pound (GBP).
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te moni Falklands whaimana ko te pauna Falkland (FKP) kua whakaritea tona uara ki te kotahi pauna o Ingarangi (GBP).
translations.true_target_text: Ko te pūtea tūturu ki te whēnua Falklands ko pāuna Faulkland (FKP), ko tōna wāriu e taurite ana ki te tāra o Ingarangi (GBP).

translations.source_text: Money can be exchanged at the only bank in the islands which is located in Stanley across from the FIC West store.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka taea te whakawhiti moni ki te peeke anake o nga motu kei Stanley kei te taha o te toa FIC West.
translations.true_target_text: Ka taea te whakawhiti i ngā moni ki ngā moutere, kei Stanley, kei tua mai i te toa FIC West.

translations.source_text: British pounds will generally be accepted anywhere in the islands and within Stanley credit cards and United States dollars are also often accepted.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga pauna o Ingarangi ka whakaaehia ki nga waahi katoa o nga moutere, kei roto hoki i nga kaari nama Stanley me nga taara o Amerika ka whakaaetia.
translations.true_target_text: Ka whakaaetia whānuitia ngā pauna Peretānia puta noa i ngā motu, ā, ki roto tonu i Stanley ka whakaaetia nuitia ngā kāri nama me ngā tāra o Ngā Whenua Tōpū o Amerika.

translations.source_text: On the outlying islands credit cards will probably not be accepted, although British and United States currency may be taken; check with the owners in advance to determine what is an acceptable payment method.
translations.pred_target_text: I nga motu o waho kaore pea e whakaaetia nga kaari nama, ahakoa ka tangohia nga moni a Ingarangi me Amerika; tirohia me nga rangatira i mua ki te whakatau he aha te tikanga utu e manakohia ana.
translations.true_target_text: Ki ngā motu matara kāore pea ngā kāri nama e whakaaetia, ahakoa ka pai pea ngā moni o Peretānia, o Ngā Whenua Tōpū o Amerika hoki; pātai atu ki ngā kaipupuri i mua atu hei whakatau he aha te tikanga utu e whakaaetia ana.

translations.source_text: It is nearly impossible to exchange Falklands currency outside of the islands, so exchange money prior to leaving the islands.
translations.pred_target_text: Kare e taea te whakawhiti moni Falklands ki waho o nga moutere, na reira me whakawhiti moni i mua i te wehe atu i nga moutere.
translations.true_target_text: Kāore nei tonu e taea te whakawhiti i te pūtea Falklands ki waho atu o te moutere, nā reira me whakawhiti koe i ō moni i mua i tō wehenga i ngā moutere.

translations.source_text: Since Montevideo is south of the Equator, it is summer there when it's winter in the Northern Hemisphere and vice versa.
translations.pred_target_text: I te mea kei te taha tonga o te Equator a Montevideo, he raumati kei reira i te takurua i te Tukoi Tukoi ki te Raki, he rereke.
translations.true_target_text: I te mea kei te tonga a Montevideo i te weheruatanga o te ao, i ngā wā e raumati ana ki reira, e takurua ana ki te Raki, ā huri kau ake hoki.

translations.source_text: Montevideo is in the subtropics; in the summer months, temperatures above +30°C are common.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko Montevideo kei roto i nga rohe iti; i nga marama o te raumati, ka kitea te mahana i runga ake i te +30°C.
translations.true_target_text: Kei ngā takiwā pārū a Montevideo; i ngā marama o te raumati ka eke noa ake i te +30 tākiri C te pāmahana.

translations.source_text: The winter can be deceptively chilly: temperatures rarely go below freezing, but the wind and humidity combine to make it feel colder than what the thermometer says.
translations.pred_target_text: He tino makariri te takurua: he iti rawa te heke o te mahana ki raro i te mīti, engari ka whakakotahi te hau me te haumākū kia makariri ake i te korero a te inemahana.
translations.true_target_text: He māminga pea te makariri o te hōtoke: kāore ngā paemahana i te tino heke iho ki raro i te kore, engari ka pāhekoheko te hau me te mākū kia makariri iho te rongo i tā te ine mahana.

translations.source_text: There are no particular "rainy" and "dry" seasons: the amount of rain stays roughly the same throughout the year.
translations.pred_target_text: Karekau he taima "ua" me "maroke": he rite tonu te nui o te ua puta noa i te tau.
translations.true_target_text: Kāore he wā ua, kāore he wā maroke: i te roanga o te tau ka pērā tonu te nui o te ua.

translations.source_text: Though many of the animals in the park are used to seeing humans, the wildlife is nonetheless wild and should not be fed or disturbed.
translations.pred_target_text: Ahakoa te maha o nga kararehe kei roto i te papa kua waia ki te kite i te tangata, he mohoao tonu te mohoao me te kore e whangaia, e whakararuraru ranei.
translations.true_target_text: He ahakoa e waia ana ngā tini kararehe ki te kite atu i te tangata, he niwhaniwha tonu ngā karerehe , ā, me kauaka e whāngai e whakahōhā rānei.

translations.source_text: According to park authorities, stay at least 100 yards/meters away from bears and wolves and 25 yards/meters from all other wild animals!
translations.pred_target_text: E ai ki nga rangatira o te papa, noho 100 iari/mita te tawhiti atu i nga pea me nga wuruhi me te 25 iari/mita mai i era atu kararehe mohoao katoa!
translations.true_target_text: E ai ki ngā mana o te pāka, me noho tonu te 100 iari/mita atu i ngā pea me ngā wuruhi me te 25 iari/mita atu i ērā atu kararehe mohoao katoa!

translations.source_text: No matter how docile they may look, bison, elk, moose, bears, and nearly all large animals can attack.
translations.pred_target_text: Noa'tu te huru o to ratou huru, te bison, te elk, te moose, te pea, me te tata ki nga kararehe nunui katoa ka taea te whakaeke.
translations.true_target_text: he ahakoa pēhea nei te kōtungatunga o te āhua, e āhei ana te pūrununui, te heka, te Tianui, te pea te āki.

translations.source_text: Each year, dozens of visitors are injured because they didn't keep a proper distance. These animals are large, wild, and potentially dangerous, so give them their space.
translations.pred_target_text: Ia tau, he maha nga manuhiri e whara ana na te mea kare ratou i noho tika. He nui, he mohoao, he morearea pea enei kararehe, no reira hoatu he waahi mo ratou.
translations.true_target_text: tau atu tau mai ka aituangia ngā tūruhi i te mea kāore i tika te tawhititanga. He nunui ēnei kararehe, he pāwhara, he mōrearea hoki pea, nāreira hoatu he maheatanga ki a rātou.

translations.source_text: In addition, be aware that odors attract bears and other wildlife, so avoid carrying or cooking odorous foods and keep a clean camp.

translations.true_target_text: Hei āpiti, kia kamakama ka hau mai ngā pea me ngā atu kararehe puihi i te mea o ngā kakara, nā me ngana kia kauka e kawe e tunu rānei i ngā kai kakara, ā, me mā hoki te puni.

translations.source_text: Apia is the capital of Samoa. The town is on the island of Upolu and has a population of just under 40,000.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko Apia te whakapaipai o Hamoa. Kei te motu o Upolu te taone nui, a, kei raro noa iho i te 40,000 te taupori.

translations.source_text: Apia was founded in the 1850s and has been the official capital of Samoa since 1959.
translations.pred_target_text: I whakatüria a Apia i te tekau tau atu i 1850, a ko ia te whakapaipai whaimana o Hamoa mai i te tau 1959.
translations.true_target_text: I whakatūria a Apia i ngā tau 1850,, ā, koirā te tāone matua ōkawa o Hāmoa mai i te tau 1959.

translations.source_text: The harbor was the site of an infamous naval standoff in 1889 when seven ships from Germany, the US, and Britain refused to leave the harbor.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te whanga te waahi o te tukinga o te moana nui i te tau 1889 i te wa e whitu nga kaipuke mai i Tiamana, i te US me Peretana i whakaae ki te wehe atu i te whanga.
translations.true_target_text: He wāhi mōiriiri te tauranga nei o tētahi pakanga tauā moana e mōhiotia ana i te kino i te tau 1889 i te wā i whanakanau ngā kaipuke e whitu mai i Tiamani, i Ngā Whenua Tōpū o Amerika, i Peretānia anō hoki ki te wehe atu i te tauranga.

translations.source_text: All the ships were sunk, except for one British cruiser. Nearly 200 American and German lives were lost.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka totohu nga kaipuke katoa, haunga te kotahi o nga waka teretere o Ingarangi. Tata ki te 200 Amerika me Tiamana i mate.
translations.true_target_text: I te totohu o ngā kaipuke katoa, atu i te kaipuke hāereere kotahi nō Peretānia. Tata ki te 200 ngā tāngata no Amerika, nō Tiamani hoki i mate.

translations.source_text: During the struggle for independence organised by the Mau movement, a peaceful gathering in the town resulted in the killing of the paramount chief Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III.
translations.pred_target_text: I te wa o te pakanga mo te mana motuhake i whakahaerea e te kaupapa Mau, he huihuinga marie i roto i te taone i mate ai te rangatira rangatira a Tupua Tamasese Lealofi III.
translations.true_target_text: I te wā o te uauatanga mō te tīno rangatiratanga te take, ko te rōpū Mau te rōpū whakahaere. I roto i te huinga mō te rongomau ka mate te ariki a Tupua Tamasese Lealofi te tuatoru.

translations.source_text: There are many beaches, due to Auckland's straddling of two harbours. The most popular ones are in three areas.
translations.pred_target_text: He maha nga takutai, na te mea e rua nga whanga o Tamaki Makaurau. Ko nga mea rongonui kei roto i nga waahi e toru.
translations.true_target_text: He maha ngā tuaone, i runga i te noho waenga a Tāmaki i ngā whanga e rua. Ko ngā mea rorotu kei ngā wāhi e toru.

translations.source_text: North Shore beaches (in North Harbour district) are on the Pacific Ocean and stretch from Long Bay in the north to Devonport in the south.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga takutai o North Shore (kei te takiwa o Te Tai Tokerau) kei te Moana-nui-a-Kiwa ka toro atu i Long Bay ki te raki ki Devonport ki te tonga.
translations.true_target_text: Ko ngā takutai ki Te Raki Paewhenua (kei Te Whanganui a Toi) kei Te Moana nui a Kiwa, e toro ana mai i Long Bay ki Devonport.

translations.source_text: They are almost all sandy beaches with safe swimming, and most have shade provided by pohutukawa trees.
translations.pred_target_text: He tata katoa nga takutai onepu me te kaukau haumaru, he marumaru te nuinga o nga rakau pohutukawa.
translations.true_target_text: Ko te nuinga o ngā moana haumaru nei, ā, ko te nuinga hoki kua whakamarua e te rākau pōhutukawa.

translations.source_text: Tamaki Drive beaches are on the Waitemata Harbour, in the upmarket suburbs of Mission Bay and St Heliers in Central Auckland.
translations.pred_target_text: Ko nga takutai o Tamaki Drive kei te whanga o Waitemata, kei te taone nui o Mission Bay me St Heliers i te puku o Tamaki Makaurau.
translations.true_target_text: Kei te Pūahatanga Waitemata ngā taha moana o Tamaki Drive, ki ngā wāhi tāone whai rawa o Mission Bay me St Heliers ki te pito o Tāmaki Makaurau.

translations.source_text: These are sometimes-crowded family beaches with a good range of shops lining the shore. Swimming is safe.
translations.pred_target_text: He takutai whanau e kiki ana i etahi wa me te maha o nga toa kei te taha o te takutai. He haumaru te kauhoe.
translations.true_target_text: I ētahi wā he wāhi i kī ana i ngā whānau tēnei moana me ngā tini toa papai e tata ana ki te tai. He kaukau haumaru.

translations.source_text: The main local beer is 'Number One', it is not a complex beer, but pleasant and refreshing. The other local beer is called "Manta".
translations.pred_target_text: Ko te pia matua o te rohe ko 'Number One', ehara i te pia uaua, engari he pai, he whakahauora. Ko tetahi atu pia o te rohe ko "Manta".
translations.true_target_text: Ko te pia ā-rohe matua ko te "Nama tahi", ehara i te pia uaua, ēngari he māma he whakarekareka. Ko te atu pia ā-rohe ko te "Manta"

translations.source_text: There are many French wines to be had, but the New Zealand and Australian wines might travel better.

translations.source_text: The local tap water is perfectly safe to drink, but bottled water is easy to find if you are fearful.

translations.source_text: For Australians, the idea of 'flat white' coffee is foreign. A short black is 'espresso', cappuccino comes heaped high with cream (not froth), and tea is served without milk.
translations.pred_target_text: Mo nga tangata o Ahitereiria, he tauhou te whakaaro o te kawhe 'flat white'. Ko te pango poto ko te 'espresso', ko te kapene karekau he kirīmi (kaore he huka), ka tukuna te ti me te kore miraka.
translations.true_target_text: Mo ngā Ahitereiria, ko te ariā mō te kawhe "papatahi mā' he manene. Ko te short black he "espresso", ko te cappuccino he kirimi kei te tihi (ehara i te whorowho), ā, karekau te tī kua ranu me te miraka.

translations.source_text: The hot chocolate is up to Belgian standards. Fruit juices are pricey but excellent.

translations.source_text: Many trips to the reef are made all year around, and injuries due to any of these causes on the reef are rare.

translations.source_text: Still, take advice from authorities, obey all signs, and pay close attention to safety warnings.

translations.true_target_text: Engari tonu, whāia ngā tohutohu a ngā rangatita, me aro hoki ki ngā tohu haumaru.

translations.source_text: Box jellyfish occur near beaches and near river estuaries from October to April north of 1770. They can occasionally be found outside these times.
translations.pred_target_text: Ka kitea nga tireni pouaka tata ki nga takutai me nga wahapu awa mai i Oketopa ki Aperira ki te raki o 1770. I etahi wa ka kitea i waho i enei waa.
translations.true_target_text: Ka kitea ngā momo Tīwai nei ki tātahi me te taha o ngā awa mai i te marama o Oketopa me Aperira, ki te raki o 1700. I ētahi ka kitea i waho atu i ēnei wā.

translations.source_text: Sharks do exist, however they rarely attack humans. Most sharks are scared of humans and would swim away.

translations.true_target_text: He mea tūturu ngā mangō, heoi anō he iti rawa tā rātou whakaeke i te tangata. Kei te mataku te nuinga o ngā mangō i te tangata, ka kaukau noa atu.

translations.source_text: Saltwater Crocodiles do not actively live in the ocean, their primary habitat is in river estuaries north from Rockhampton.

translations.true_target_text: Kāore ngā waitā korokotaira e tīno noho ki rō moana, ko tō rātou tīno wāhi noho ko ngā awaawa kei te raki o Rockhampton.

translations.source_text: Booking in advance gives the traveller peace of mind that they will have somewhere to sleep once they arrive at their destination.

translations.source_text: Travel agents often have deals with specific hotels, although you may find it possible to book other forms of accommodation, like camping grounds, through a travel agent.

translations.source_text: Travel agents usually offer packages that include breakfast, transportation arrangements to/from the airport or even combined flight and hotel packages.

translations.true_target_text: He rite tonu te tuku a ngā kaiwhakarite hāereere i ngā kete kei roto rā ko te parakuihi, ngā whakaritenga ikiiki ki/atu i te tauranga wakarererangi, ngā kete paheko i te rerenga me te hōtēra rānei.

translations.source_text: They can also hold the reservation for you if you need time to think about the offer or procure other documents for your destination (e.g. visa).

translations.true_target_text: Ka taea hoki e rātou te pupuri i te whakaritenga māu ki te hiahia wā koe hei whakaaro ki te tukunga, ki te whiwhi rānei i ētahi atu puka mō te wāhi ka torohia e koe (hei tauira, he pane uruuruwhenua).

translations.source_text: Any amendments or requests though should be coursed through the travel agent first and not directly with the hotel.

translations.true_target_text: Tukuna ngā whakatikatika me ngā tono ki te kaitiaki haereere i te tuatahi, kaua ko te hōtēra.

translations.source_text: For some festivals, the vast majority of the attendants to music festivals decide to camp on site, and most attendants consider it a vital part of the experience.
